title-group.article-title: Potential of Negative Valve Overlap for Part-Load Efficiency Improvement in Gasoline Engines

abstract.p: This article reports on the potential of negative valve overlap (NVO) for improving the net indicated thermal efficiency (η NIMEP) of gasoline engines during part load. Three fixed fuel flow rates, resulting in indicated mean effective pressures of up to 6 bar, were investigated. At low load, NVO significantly reduces the pumping loses during the gas exchange loop, achieving up to 7% improvement in indicated efficiency compared to the baseline. Similar efficiency improvements are achieved by positive valve overlap (PVO), with the disadvantage of worse combustion stability from a higher residual gas fraction (xr). As the load increases, achieving the wide-open throttle limit, the benefits of NVO for reducing the pumping losses diminish, while the blowdown losses from early exhaust valve opening (EVO) increase. However, a symmetric NVO strategy combined with a shorter exhaust duration has a higher potential for reduction in part-load fuel consumption, as the EVO timing can be optimized to minimize the blowdown losses.

caption.p: Operating points on the engine map (midsize sedan vehicle, 2.5-L NA engine with a compression ratio of 11.5:1) determined using Autonomie over the UDDS cycle. Spark timings at maximum brake torque (MBT) timing. Adapted from Jo, 2016 [1]. © SAE International
Pressure-volume diagram for a part-load operation in SI engines (logarithmic scales) at 3.75-bar NIMEP. © SAE International

Valve timing diagram for the engine used. The intake and exhaust valve openings have a duration of 220°CA. The position shown on the left is the stock valve timing with de-energized variable valve timing (VVT) solenoids. The black arrows represent the direction of phasing for NVO. The position shown on the right is the most aggressive NVO pursued, with de-energized VVT solenoids. © SAE International
Specifications of the base engine, stock parked valve timing. © SAE International
Diagram of the experimental setup and measurement points. © SAE International

Valve timing experiment matrix. The two black stars represent the parked valve timing settings (i.e., no VVT actuation) used to cover the valve timing map. The orange and blue squares represent the range covered by the VVT system from the corresponding parked valve timings. © SAE International
Positive and negative valve overlap regions as a function of valve timing. The bigger green points highlight the individual valve timings that will be discussed in detail. © SAE International
Engine operating points investigated. © SAE International

Change in net indicated thermal efficiency (ηNIMEP) as a function of valve overlap. Different valve timing settings can result in the same valve overlap. The results shown correspond to the greatest positive change in efficiency observed for a given valve overlap. © SAE International
Valve timings for which the pressure traces are analyzed in detail. © SAE International
ηNIMEP as a function of valve timing for a constant fuel injection of 14.7 mg per cylinder per cycle. © SAE International
Relative change in ηNIMEP with respect to the baseline valve (fuel mass = 14.7 mg/cyl./cycle). © SAE International
Combustion stability, CoV (top) and LNV (bottom), as a function of valve timing for a constant fuel injection of 14.7 mg per cylinder per cycle. © SAE International
Comparison of the pumping loops (logarithmic scales) of the baseline and symmetric PVO valve timings (fuel mass = 14.7 mg/cyl./cycle). © SAE International
xr as a function of valve timing for a constant fuel injection of 14.7 mg per cylinder per cycle. © SAE International
log(P)-log(V) diagrams for baseline and late IVO valve timings for a constant fuel injection of 14.7 mg per cylinder per cycle. © SAE International
Comparison of the pumping loops (linear scales) of the baseline and late IVO valve timings (fuel mass = 14.7 mg/cyl./cycle). © SAE International
log(P)-log(V) diagrams for baseline and early EVC valve timings for a constant fuel injection of 14.7 mg per cylinder per cycle. © SAE International
Comparison of the high-pressure loops (linear scales) of the baseline and early EVC valve timings (fuel mass = 14.7 mg/cyl./cycle). © SAE International
Comparison of the pumping loops (linear scales) of the baseline and early EVC valve timings (fuel mass = 14.7 mg/cyl./cycle). © SAE International
log(P)-log(V) diagrams for baseline and symmetric NVO valve timings for a constant fuel injection of 14.7 mg per cylinder per cycle. © SAE International
Comparison of the pumping loops (linear scales) of the baseline and symmetric NVO valve timings (fuel mass = 14.7 mg/cyl./cycle). © SAE International
